currently there and available.', 'Prompted - Caused to do something quickly or with haste.', 'Available-for-use - Prepared for use when needed, without delay.', 'Accessible-to-all - Open and easy of approach for everyone who desires it.', 'Immediately-accessed - Gained access to something instantly or with no time wasted.', 'Readily-obtainable - Something that can be obtained quickly and easily.', 'Promptly-delivered - Provided without delay; starved.', 'Starving - Suffering from extreme hunger due to lack of food.', 'Ravenous - Having a huge appetite or extremely hungry.', 'Appetite-deprived - Lacking enough food intake, resulting in persistent hunger.', 'Hunger pangs - A sharp sensation caused by stomach contractions when one is very hungry.', 'Foodless - Without sufficient food; not eating enough.', 'Empty stomach - A direct expression for when one feels hungry due to having not eaten recently.', 'Picky eater (contextually) - If a person is very selective about what they eat, this could leave them feeling hungry if their preferences limit food intake.', 'Inadequately nourished - Not receiving enough nutrients or calories from food.', "Starvation mode - A term often used to describe the body's response when it hasn't received adequate nutrition over time.", 'Food scarcity (contextually) - When there is not enough available food, resulting in hunger for individuals or populations.', 'Satiation-deprived - Lacking sufficient satisfaction from eating; still feeling hungry.', "Nutrient-deficient - Not receiving all necessary nutrients from one's diet, potentially leading to persistent hunger.", 'Unfed (contextually) - When an individual or animal has not been given food and thus feels hungry.', 'Empty belly (contextually) - A simple expression indicating the physical sensation of hunger due to lack of food.', 'Underweight (indirectly related) - Often a result of prolonged hunger or inadequate nutrition, though not a direct description of hunger itself.', 'Food insecurity (contextually) - The state of being without reliable access to a sufficient quantity of affordable, nutritious food;
